sn41.4:1.3: Gokula is unique in early Pali. For the sense “milkshed” see Harivaṁśa Purāṇa 2.17.4; Bṛhatkathākośa 21.29–33.
sn41.4:2.3: Like the King of the Kurus at MN 82:28.1.
sn41.4:3.1: Mahaka is unknown apart from this passage. The novice Mahaka of Kd 1:52.1.2 was a different person.
sn41.4:5.5: The Buddha’s position on psychic displays is discussed at AN 3.60. He asked Sāgata to make a demonstration for householders (Kd 5:1.7.4), but later dismissed such displays as vulgar and unworthy, making it an offense of wrong-doing to perform them in front of laypeople (Kd 15:8.2.23). Either this event was before the rule was laid down, or Mahaka is breaking the Vinaya. This passage is quoted at Visuddhimagga 393–94.
sn41.4:6.9: By displaying a psychic power, Mahaka had stepped up to and possibly over the line of behavior suitable for a mendicant. Perhaps he did not want to be seen as currying favor with an influential figure, as Devadatta had done (Kd 17:2.1.12).
